title: 'Them boys was lights out': Chiefs size up Matt Moore's start in place of Patrick Mahomes
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Believe it or not we have all but reached the halfway point of the NFL regular season. As Lorenzo Reyes details, the league's elite class is starting to crystalize. USA TODAY

KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Damien Wilson didn’t even wait until question’s end before he interjected.

“Awesome,” the Chiefs linebacker told USA TODAY Sports after the Green Bay Packers’ 31-24 win. “Them boys was lights out. They played absolutely amazing.”

The Chiefs defense doled out praise along those lines to the Aaron Rodgers-Aaron Jones attack that outlasted relentless pressure from defenders like Wilson.

But Wilson’s praise for boys playing lights out wasn’t for Rodgers and his again-spectacular playmaking. It wasn’t for the five-sack, 12-hit Whack-a-Rodgers effort to which Wilson contributed three hits and one sack. (Through the Packers’ first seven games, Rodgers was hit an average of 4.2.)

No, Wilson’s praise for absolutely amazing play was how he characterized backup quarterback Matt Moore’s first start in place of reigning NFL MVP Patrick Mahomes. Teammates across the Chiefs locker room agreed.

“He’s been in the league for a while, he’s seen a lot of defenses and he knows a lot of calls,” linebacker Anthony Hitchens told USA TODAY Sports. “That’s exactly why they brought him up.”

Added tight end Travis Kelce: “Played outstanding. The ball was right there every time I can think of.”

MORE: 32 things we learned from Week 8

OPINION: Patriots have elite component -- and it's not Tom Brady

4th & MONDAY: Our NFL newsletter always brings the blitz

Matt Moore threw for 267 yards and two touchdowns against the Packers. (Photo: Jay Biggerstaff, USA TODAY Sports)

The Chiefs lamented their third loss. But they didn’t lament Moore’s play.

Moore last started a game in the NFL nearly two years ago, on Nov. 26, 2017. He last started a game he didn’t turn the ball over in 2,884 days ago (a December 2011 win vs. Oakland). So sure, teammates insisted, Moore’s veteran experience might have helped him learn the playbook, incorporate smoothly into Andy Reid’s offense and spread around balls to Chiefs targets with poise.

But that doesn’t guarantee execution when replacing the league’s reigning MVP in Patrick Mahomes (dislocated right kneecap). Moore’s 24-of-36 night with 267 yards, two touchdowns, no turnovers and a 107.1 passer rating qualified as more than game management.

Take his 29-yard touchdown to Kelce in the second quarter.

Moore faked a handoff to Chiefs receiver Tyreek Hill before lobbing a ball right toward the end zone where Kelce was headed. The play was one that the Chiefs had drawn up and practiced during the week’s game prep. But the practice run hadn’t generated as much pressure as Moore encountered when Packers defensive end Dean Lowry and outside linebacker Rashan Gary beat their blocks and readied to crush Moore.

Matt Moore lofts the TD to Travis Kelce! (Via @NFL) pic.twitter.com/bDASsQsJZF — USA TODAY NFL (@usatodaynfl) October 28, 2019

“I had to get rid of it a little sooner than we anticipated,” Moore explained afterward.

Kelce hadn’t yet turned out where Moore needed him to complete the play. So the 35-year-old lobbed the pass to buy time for his tight end. It worked. The Chiefs were on the board after opening in a 14-point hole. They’d score 17 unanswered before halftime, as Moore kept pace with Rodgers through three quarters.

In fact, entering the fourth, each team was at 17. Rodgers had completed 69 percent of throws (20-of-29) for 227 yards, one touchdown and a 103.7 passer rating. Moore had connected on 67 percent (18-of-27) for 209 yards, two scores and a 114.6 rating (Rodgers had taken four more sacks).

The Chiefs answered the Packers’ five-play, 27-yard scoring drive with a 10-play, 75-yard march to the end zone of their own. But Rodgers and Aaron Jones’ last stab — Rodgers to Jones in the backfield almost simultaneously with the snap, that Jones took 67 yards to the house — was one too many.

Chiefs coach Andy Reid on Packers QB Aaron Rodgers: "A future Hall of Fame quarterback with a couple of Hall of Fame throws. I don't know how a couple of those got in there [but] the son of a got them in there."



(📹: @NFL)pic.twitter.com/HwVNYp4TjD — Jori Epstein (@JoriEpstein) October 28, 2019

Moore hit Kelce on third-and-3 long enough to move the chains, but Packers cornerback Chandler Sullivan reached in front of Kelce and batted down the pass before the tight end could secure it. The Chiefs punted on fourth-and-3 and didn’t get the ball back.

“Aaron Rodgers just being Aaron Rodgers,” Chiefs safety Tyrann Mathieu said simply.

But as Mahomes waited in the tunnel hallway outside the Chiefs' locker room with his brother and girlfriend, his teammates told reporters that Moore’s performance reassured them for the one or two more games before Mahomes’ return from rehab. Moore already identified areas in his footwork, throwing motion and pocket presence vs. the Packers that he wants to correct. He said he felt nervous, naturally, but not rusty. Another good sign: The Chiefs didn’t need to simplify their game plan without Mahomes.

“He was ready,” Chiefs coach Andy Reid said. “He spent a lot of time at it. We didn’t hold a lot back and you can’t against a team like this.

“He stepped his game up. He wanted everything. He attacked it during the week and studied. Like I said, he did a respectable job.”

Follow USA TODAY Sports' Jori Epstein on Twitter @JoriEpstein.

If you love talking football, we have the perfect spot for you. Join our Facebook Group, The Ruling Off the Field, to engage in friendly debate and conversation with fellow football fans and our NFL insiders. What are you waiting for?
description: Playing in the place of injured QB Patrick Mahomes, Matt Moore performed admirably, despite the Chiefs losing at home to the Packers.
